column5: Look closely when walking through the mossy trees of Shiratani Unsuikyo forest–there might be kodama, or tree spirits, nearby.It’s dense with greenery and very quiet, sound absorbed by the thick moss. Gentle creeks trickle over ancient rocks, through the fine selectionof cedars only found in Japan, and which are named for it (they are called “yakusugi” or “Yakushima cedars”). There are hiking trails too, some of which dateback to the Edo period (the 17th through mid-19th centuries).It is also notable because it served as an inspiration for Studio Ghibli’sPrincess Mononoke, which addresses the tension between humans and nature spirits in the forest setting. Lead artist Kazuo Oga was said to have spent many hours sketching the forest in preparation for the film.
column6: The magical, mossy forest that inspired Princess Mononoke.
column7: ['Sun Messe Nichinan', 'Ame no Sakahoko', 'Crepe Vending Machine']
